channel.title: Mac OS X + Vista
channel.description:
So on my newest computer I want to be able to have both OS's. I haven't owned a Mac since PowerPC days, like Mac 7. Computer will have Vista 64 preinstalled.
So I've found a few guides on dual-booting, so I'm assuming it can be done. It used to not be able to, you could only emulate one or the other. And I know you can have Vista etc on a Mac. So now I guess you can vice versa.
My question is:
Is there a 64 bit version of Leopard? If so, are there any bugs or shit?

item.title: Mac OS X + Vista
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

double post ftw I just prefer ms office, its alot sleeker and the UI is more friendly to use, especially with the way its set out in 07/10 products. No more trawling through menus to find what you need when its right there and waiting for you.

Read full topic

item.title: Mac OS X + Vista
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“sanga282, post:27, topic:284916”][quote author=bowserjr2 link=topic=376545.msg2840625#msg2840625 date=1245948733]

Well IIRC, Mac’s check for something hardware based that they put in there. And Windows PCs don’t put them in there. So…

I don’t know. I don’t want to spend time trying that if it won’t work =/

@T4_: Then why does the Graphic community (not just hobby-ists, I’m talking huge companies) use it? What better option is there?

Your 1st statement: Read: http://uneasysilence.com/os-x-proven-hacked-and-running-on-an-ordinary-pc/

Your 2nd statement: Because they’re misguided, they could buy better machines and install Unix/Linux on them for less than the price per Mac. *nix variants have free, open source applications that will perform the same tasks. Also, *nix machines can be used to create a parallel processor (CPU or GPU) farm.

because the majority of the open source applications are shit compared to their proprietary counterparts.

Photoshop -> Gimp
Nero -> DeVeDe + K3b
MS Office -> Openoffice
iTunes -> GTKPod
MSNMessenger -> Pidgin

I don’t see your logic in stating the ‘majority’ of open source software is worse than proprietary. I will admit, however, that Photoshop is better in most cases than Gimp.

winamp is obviously better and open office sucks dick

What is wrong with OpenOffice and GTKPod?
[/quote]
nothing wrong with GTKPod but winamp is better, and open office is just bad in comparison to MS office. Price wise yeah sure its better, but i torrented MS office so the price isnt an issue[/quote]
Winamp sucks, Amarok and VLC are much better. OpenOffice is much better than MS Office, why do you think it is better?

SomethingToHide:

OpenOffice is cool, and I’ve installed it for a few people, but I’ve always had a pirated Office, so why switch?

I’ve always used OO; it’s just easier, smaller size, etc.

Read full topic

item.title: Mac OS X + Vista
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

SomethingToHide:

OpenOffice is cool, and I’ve installed it for a few people, but I’ve always had a pirated Office, so why switch?

No need to switch then, use the best from Opensource and cloosedSource. Despite what Mopar say OpenSource is not the best choose for everyone and will not save the world.

Read full topic

item.title: Mac OS X + Vista
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

The majority? I wouldn’t go that far. When you’re talking about things like video editing suites and audio workstations though, we are talking about apps that are really really really established (Logic is on version 8) have been around for a long time (late 80s, which is basically when the market it targets was invented) and have a dedicated audience cuz of the steep learning curve and sheer amount they’re used in peoples daily lives (spend 10 hours a day sitting in front of one app for 10 years and then try and switch to another :/)

Thats something open source alternatives will find hard to top, whether theyre better or not…

Read full topic

item.title: Mac OS X + Vista
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

ProTools is much better on a Mac, and that’s another example I was going to use.

The type of software used in the industry can’t be matched by any Linux counterparts.

Read full topic

item.title: Mac OS X + Vista
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Actually, in some cases, mac DOES have the better software.

Logic no longer runs on a PC. Pro Tools (I am told) runs better on a Mac than a PC. That’s pretty much the top 2 DAWs then. PC has Cubase, which is a well-used piece of software, but it has nowhere near the market share of PT and Logic. If I could afford a Mac, I’d have one to run Logic on.

Read full topic

item.title: Mac OS X + Vista
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

The bigg houses make their own programs most of the time, but almost everything else uses Macs because it’s the industry standard.

Example. Final Cut Pro. Mac only basically. That’s the industry standard. It has all the plugins they need and they can write their own for it if need be.

What Linux program would do that justice?

They’re not going to switch all their shit because Linux MIGHT run a little better for them after a shit ton of work.

Read full topic

item.title: Mac OS X + Vista
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:

Your 2nd statement: Because they’re misguided, they could buy better machines and install Unix/Linux on them for less than the price per Mac. *nix variants have free, open source applications that will perform the same tasks. Also, *nix machines can be used to create a parallel processor (CPU or GPU) farm.

Read full topic

In fact, it’s used by most of the people in the design industry. Audio/video etc.

And I’m not looking for 100%. I’d be using it for about 3-4 different programs every now and then, sometimes more sometimes not.[/quote]
Overpriced, proprietary software (and hardware) thats best feature is looking ‘pretty’… You sure it doesn’t suck?

Read full topic
